title: Registration - Closed
text:
‚Ä¢ We want to: Create free, open-source resources to support and facilitate evidence-informed decision making and address health policy needs in Kenya.
‚Ä¢ We are looking for:

Public Health Decision-Makers: Ministry of Health officials and public health specialists who provide insights based on real-world public health needs and ensure developed tools address practical challenges.
Developers and Technical Experts: Individuals proficient in R programming, version control using Git and GitHub, epidemiological modelling, and software development.
Academics and Researchers: Participants from various Kenyan institutions, not limited to CEMA, who are involved in infectious disease modelling and public health data analysis.

‚Ä¢ We aim to: maximize diversity in skills, experiences, and people.
‚Ä¢ Applications close on the 5th December 2024.


There is no cost to attend the hackathon, however, there are a limited number of places available for the hackathon. While we do have some funds to support travel and attendance for participants from outside Nairobi and from MRC-GIDA at Imperial College London, these funds are limited. If you require financial support to attend, please indicate this in the registration form.



Registration Is Now Closed!
Please register your interest for the hackathon using the link above by 3 December 24. We will then be in touch to confirm participant funding and attendance, which will be allocated to ensure a diverse range of participants and backgrounds.

If you require financial support to attend, please indicate this in the registration form.

title: Bridging The Gap Hackathon
text:
Karibu Sana & Welcome





Who is here: Over 50 public health researchers, decision makers and software development experts from Kenya and UK.
Why we‚Äôre here: To solve health policy needs in Kenya, foster new ideas, and make meaningful connections.
What‚Äôs next: A week of collaboration, creativity, and ‚òï & üç™.

We will be taking photos throughout for social media. Smile! üì∑

https://mrc-ide.github.io/cema-mrc-hackathon/feedback.html

title: Bridging The Gap Hackathon
text:
Why are we here today?

Saw the hackathon advertised and wanted to see what it was about.
Wanted to leave the cold weather in the UK behind. ü•∂ ‚úàÔ∏è ‚òÄÔ∏è
To create free, open-source resources to support and facilitate evidence-informed decision making and address health policy needs in Kenya.



All of the above

title: Bridging The Gap Hackathon
text:
Why are we all here?





What brought us here is behind us - let‚Äôs try to focus on what we can do this week.
So let‚Äôs start by taking a moment to pause, breath and shift our focus to the space we are sharing this week.
Most importantly, this week is an opportunity to connect, share knowledge, and build useful tools and relationships from this hackathon.

title: Bridging The Gap Hackathon
text:
What is a hackathon?
Meeting of individuals with diverse interests and skill sets, working in groups to build new software tools and solutions.

Step 1: Sharing ideas for questions to answer by building new software tools
Step 2: Sharing research skills and interests in the ideas shared
Step 3: Identifying the top ideas and software to work on
Step 4: Formation of groups to work on each identified project

text:

title: Bridging The Gap Hackathon
text:
Hackathon Topic Presentations

Cold Chain Capacity Monitoring:

Streamline reporting and visualising vaccine cold chain capacity.

Outbreak Alert Thresholds:

Refining epidemic thresholds for measles outbreak detection.

Data Quality Validation:

Automating detection of anomalies in vaccine data for better accuracy.

Schistosomiasis Elimination Strategies:

Conduct cost-effectiveness evaluation of elimination strategies.

Malaria Vaccine Deployment:

Optimising malaria vaccination with with other interventions.

Animal Surveillance Data Integration:

Unified platform for real-time animal health data analysis and reporting.

Your affiliation, e.g.¬†CEMA




Data Analysis & Statistics (Statistical analysis, Data analysis, Predictive modelling, Stochastic modelling)

Machine Learning & AI (Machine learning, AI-driven solutions, Bayesian inference, Time-series prediction)

Epidemiology & Modelling (Epidemiological modelling, Mathematical modelling, Infectious disease dynamics, Climate-sensitive VPDs)

Public Health & Policy (Public health policy, Public health management, Evidence synthesis, Vaccine impact estimation)

Health Economics (Health economics, Cost-effectiveness analysis)

Software Engineering (Software development, R packaging,Python programming, Web applications)

Data Engineering (Data algorithms, Database management, Interoperability, Integrations expert)

Visualisation & Reporting (Data visualisation, Dashboards and tools)

Communication & Knowledge Translation (Knowledge translation, Communications strategy)

Project Management & Leadership (Project management, Leadership in public health)

title: Bridging The Gap Hackathon
section: Project A: Cold Chain Capacity Monitoring
text:
Project A: Cold Chain Capacity Monitoring
Key Proposed Tools/Ideas:

Develop IoT-based cold chain monitoring sensors. Example: ‚ÄúAdd an indicator in KHIS for monthly reporting of cold chain capacity and equipment functionality.‚Äù
Create an app for real-time temperature alerts. Example: ‚ÄúEnable automated temperature monitoring with real-time notifications for deviations.‚Äù
Design an automated cold chain capacity planner. Example: ‚ÄúDevelop predictive models to estimate cold chain needs based on vaccine demand trends.‚Äù


Assigned Participants:

Philip M, Stephanie K, Bonventre A, Peninna N, Fathiya H, Peter M, Jackine N

title: Bridging The Gap Hackathon
text:
Project B: Outbreak Alert Thresholds
Key Proposed Tools/Ideas:

Develop a user-friendly data visualisation dashboard. Example: ‚ÄúCreate visuals to track outbreak alerts and response timelines.‚Äù
Automate data validation processes. Example: ‚ÄúIntegrate systems to validate alert thresholds against historical data.‚Äù
Implement a centralised database for data integration. Example: ‚ÄúDevelop a unified platform to consolidate outbreak reports from multiple regions.‚Äù


Assigned Participants:

Stanley S, Giovanni C, Salmon G, Pius K, Ivy K, Florence A, Lydiah K, Amika P

title: Bridging The Gap Hackathon
text:
Project C: Data Quality Validation
Key Proposed Tools/Ideas:

Create a data quality scoring system. Example: ‚ÄúAutomate data validation checks for anomalies in health records.‚Äù
Design a dashboard for tracking data anomalies. Example: ‚ÄúDevelop real-time analytics for monitoring data quality metrics.‚Äù
Automate alerts for outliers in data submissions. Example: ‚ÄúEnable system-generated notifications for inconsistencies in vaccination data.‚Äù


Assigned Participants:

Ommet EO, Cosmas B, Muchiri Antony, Paul L, Katy G, Fred M

title: Bridging The Gap Hackathon
text:
Project E: Malaria Vaccine Deployment
Key Proposed Tools/Ideas:

Create a vaccine deployment tracker. Example: ‚ÄúTrack malaria vaccine rollout progress at the sub-county level.‚Äù
Develop GIS tools to map vaccine coverage. Example: ‚ÄúVisualise vaccine distribution areas to identify coverage gaps.‚Äù
Design an algorithm to optimise vaccine distribution. Example: ‚ÄúSimulate distribution scenarios to ensure equitable vaccine access.‚Äù


Assigned Participants:

Tabitha O, Augustine M, Geoffrey G, Mumbua M, Daniel B, Pete W, Omar Ahmes, Anne K

title: Bridging The Gap Hackathon
section: Project F: Animal Surveillance Data Integration
text:
Project F: Animal Surveillance Data Integration
Key Proposed Tools/Ideas:

Develop spillover risk mapping tools. Example: ‚ÄúMap high-risk areas for zoonotic disease spillovers based on surveillance data.‚Äù
Automate surveillance reporting systems. Example: ‚ÄúStreamline submission of surveillance data to improve reporting efficiency.‚Äù
Implement interoperability features between animal and human surveillance. Example: ‚ÄúIntegrate animal health data into human surveillance platforms for coordinated response.‚Äù


Assigned Participants:

Ryan M, Anne K, Purity K, Ruth M, Annah M, Mumbua M, Emmanuel O, Argni B

title: Bridging The Gap Hackathon
text:
Project G: Workforce Estimation
Key Proposed Tools/Ideas:

Develop a workforce simulation tool. Example: ‚ÄúModel staffing requirements for vaccination campaigns.‚Äù
Create a training needs assessment platform. Example: ‚ÄúIdentify skill gaps and design targeted training programs for health workers.‚Äù
Design a dashboard to monitor workforce metrics. Example: ‚ÄúTrack workforce deployment and utilisation in real-time.‚Äù


Assigned Participants:

Komundia G, Sabine van E, Ojal T, Penina MN, Francis M, Moses M

title: Day 3
text:
Presentation Format

Background: Context, rationale and objective of your project
Demonstration: Live (or semi-live/screenshots) demonstration of your tool
Technical Overview: Description of the methods, technical workings of your tool
Policy Value: How do you anticipate this tool to meet a policy need? Are there any other audiences or stakeholders who may want to see this tool?
Next Steps: What did you not manage to cover this week? What features would you want to still add?
Maintenance Plan: Who from CEMA will be taking this project forward?

title: Day 3
text:
Further Updates

Please, please, please all respond to Waithera‚Äôs email for dinner updates
Think Big.

On Friday, we will have time for groups to plan how to take this work forward:

Conference Abstracts?
Journal Submission?
Grant Applications?

However, there is no reason to not also think about the above now:

Could someone in your group be spending time writing up your work as a short paper?
Is there a conference you have in mind already? Maybe start writing an abstract?

title: Introduction to Git
text:
Introduction to Git

Git is a version control software (VCS).
VCS: Takes a picture of what your files look like and stores that in memory.
This allows us to look back and see how our files have changed over time.

title: Introduction to Git
section: Why do we need version control?
text: Why do we need version control?

title: Introduction to Git
text:
Version control: metadata + history

who: name of person making changes
when: date and time change
what: contents of files changed
why: motivation for the change

title: Introduction to Git
section: Is it just like a backup?
text:
Is it just like a backup?

Why not just use Dropbox?
Or Google Drive?
These are also great to use, and Google docs for example has version control where changes are tracked.
However, Git and Github are made specifically for tracking how codebases have changed.

title: Introduction to Git
text:
Installing Git
Git supports all operating systems. You can install it using command-line tools or directly download and install the setup.
https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Getting-Started-Installing-Git

Linux

For Debian/Ubuntu-based operating systems use apt-get install git or similar.

macOS

If you have homebrew installed, use this command to download and install Git: brew install git.

Windows

Installing Git on Windows is hassle-free. Just go to the download page

title: Introduction to Git
section: How to check if you have installed Git?
text:
How to check if you have installed Git?
Open a terminal, type git --version and press enter

title: Introduction to Git
text:
Link Git to your Github
git config --global user.name "your-user-name"
git config --global user.email "your@email.com"

title: Introduction to Git
text:
Basic git terms

repository: (or ‚Äúrepo‚Äù) git‚Äôs database. Might be local or on GitHub
working copy: all the files you actually work with
commit:

as a noun: a snapshot of all the files in the repository
as a verb: create a snapshot

hash: fingerprint of a file/repository

title: Introduction to Git
text: Git history

title: Introduction to Git
text:
Interacting with Git

From the command line - always good to be comfortable with this
From a GUI

RStudio has one built-in
Most IDEs do now (e.g.¬†VSCode or Positron)

Via GitHub

title: Introduction to Git
text:
Basic git commands

git init: initialise a repository
git add: stage files
git commit: add staged files to the repository by making a commit
git log: see an overview of what changed
git diff: see details of what changed

title: Introduction to Git
text: End of part 1

title: Introduction to Git
text: What makes a commit?

title: Introduction to Git
text:
Ideally

One set of related changes
Commit message explains why they were needed
Short title (<60 characters)
Blank line, then any further discussion

title: Introduction to Git
text:
Not everything goes in git

Large files
Passwords
Outputs (sometimes)
Use .gitignore

title: Introduction to Git
text:
Remote git commands

git clone: download a repository
git fetch: update remote changes but don‚Äôt apply them
git pull: update remote changes and do apply them
git push: send your changes upstream
git remote: inspect / change details of upstream repositories
git branch: inspect / create a branch
git checkout -b: create a branch and change to it (yes this is stupid)
git merge: merge branches

title: Introduction to Git
text:
Rstudio and GitHub

Not all commands are supported but all you will likely need
Use the shell for the rest

title: Kariithi Anne Wanjiku
text:
Anne is a computer at the Center for Epidemiological Modelling and Analysis, developing data algorithms, pipelines, and database management systems to support public health policymaking. She hopes to advance her studies in biomedical engineering to improve patient outcomes through innovative applications in computational bioengineering. By integrating her engineering expertise with her passion for healthcare accessibility, she aims to advance healthcare technology, especially in underserved communities.


 Back to top

title: Triza Shigoli
text:
Triza Shigoli is a Project Management and Organizational Development professional, and the Administrative Manager at the Center for Epidemiological Modelling and Analysis (CEMA), with experience in supporting the delivery of health research projects in collaboration with a multidisciplinary team of scientists and technical experts.


 Back to top

title: Stanley Sayianka
text:
Stanley Sayianka is a Data Science Research Assistant at the Centre for Epidemiological Modelling and Analysis (CEMA). His work focuses on the statistical modeling of mortality indicators.


 Back to top

title: George Kamundia Mbugua
text:
George Kamundia is a data science intern at the Center for Epidemiological Modelling and Analysis (CEMA), applying data analytics to inform public health decision-making. He focuses on developing predictive models and tools that bridge the gap between data science and health policy, contributing to more effective disease control and prevention strategies.


 Back to top

title: Muchiri Antony Mutwiri
text:
Muchiri Antony M is a software engineer intern at CEMA, where he works on optimizing various aspects of the CEMA Analytics Hub. With a strong foundation in technology and problem-solving, he is dedicated to developing impactful solutions that address real-world challenges.


 Back to top

title: Giovanni Charles
text:
Giovanni Charles is a software/ML engineer working on surrogates for infectious disease transmission models for inference and optimisation. He is interested in normalising flows, LLM interfaces for ID models, surrogate modelling, Bayesian inference, time-series prediction, differentiable agent based modelling and JAX.


 Back to top

title: John Nalwa
text:
John Wakhungu is a software developer at InnoSoft Technologies, specializing in custom software development, data analysis, and web applications. He is passionate about leveraging technology to solve real-world challenges, including public health innovation and data-driven solutions.


 Back to top

title: Florence Akinyi
text: Back to top

title: Ryan Musasia
text:
I‚Äôm a freshly minted Data Scientist who just escaped the clutches of academia and is ready to conquer the data-driven world with wit, charm, and a whole lot of Python magic. My expertise lies in unraveling intricate data puzzles rather than solving crimes. My core competencies revolve around employing machine learning, statistical analysis, and advanced methodologies to extract valuable insights from complex datasets. My passion lies in uncovering concealed information within data and converting it into actionable intelligence that drives informed decision-making. Rest assured, there‚Äôs no sorcery involved (well, at least not beyond the occasional code magic).


 Back to top

title: Amika Patel
text:
I am Amika Patel, a data analyst at the Nairobi West Hospital. With experience in healthcare operations and a passion for using data to drive evidence-based policies, I am keen to bridge the gap between analytics and real-world decision-making.


 Back to top

title: Annah Mudamba
text: Back to top

title: Augustine Masinde
text: Back to top

title: Thumbi Mwangi
text:
Thumbi Mwangi Co-Director & Group Lead (Applied Epidemiology) at CEMA, leading efforts in epidemiological modelling and public health policy in Africa. He is an infectious disease epidemiologist combining classical epidemiology, applied epidemiological modelling and data science to improve the speed and quality of policy decision making in human and animal health


 Back to top

title: Francis Ondicho Motiri
text:
Francis Motiri is a postgraduate in the field of epidemiology and a holder of a master of science in medical statistics from the University of Nairobi. Currently working in the ministry of health as health work force analyst .


 Back to top

title: Emmanuel Okunga
text: Back to top

title: Lydiah Khalayi
text: Back to top

title: Moses Muriithi
text:
Moses Muriithi is an health economist and an associate professor at the university of Nairobi department of economics and development studies cost effectiveness of various diseases interventions in the era of digital technology.


 Back to top

title: Dominic Makana Ocharo
text:
Dominic Makana Ocharo is a telecommunications engineer and data scientist based in Kenya, specializing in developing AI-driven solutions and data analytics tools to address public health challenges and optimize decision-making in resource-constrained settings.


 Back to top

title: Geoffrey Githinji
text:
Geoffrey is a research fellow at CEMA working of models of malaria interventions. In this role, he is supporting national malaria control programs by leveraging disease modelling and data analytics to inform strategic decisions and operational plans.


 Back to top

title: Mumbua Mutunga
text:
Mumbua Mutunga is a PhD student at the University of Nairobi, working on rabies and the various ways to optimise the disease interventions towards accelerating disease elimination in Kenya.


 Back to top

title: Ruth Mc Cabe
text:
Ruth McCabe is a statistician and mathematical modeller at Imperial College London specialising in outbreak response at the science-policy interface.


 Back to top

title: Pius Kariuki
text:
Pius Kariuki is a digital health engineer at IntelliSOFT consulting, working with cross sectional data with tools like DHIS2. I am also an interoperability and integrations expert working with standards like FHIR and FHIR-data-pipes to report patient data.


 Back to top

title: John Ojal
text:
John Ojal is a post-doctoral researcher at the Kenya Medical Research Institute - Wellcome Trust, focusing on epidemiological modeling and health economics, with contributions to studies on pneumococcal vaccination and COVID-19 in Kenya


 Back to top

title: Bonventure Ameyo
text:
Dr.¬†Ameyo has gathered experience both in the practice and delivery of healthcare, its programming and management in the public sector in Kenya, currently working as the deputy director medical services in Turkana County, Kenya.


 Back to top

title: Omar Ahmed
text:
My name is Omar Ahmed, and I am currently pursuing my Master‚Äôs in Public Health. I work in public health in Mombasa County, where I focus on designing and implementing health programs to improve community well-being. My thesis research explores the association between malaria prevalence in children under five and demographic, socio-economic, and environmental factors in Mogadishu. I am passionate about using evidence-based approaches to tackle public health challenges, especially in vulnerable populations. I‚Äôm excited to be here and look forward to learning and collaborating with all of you.‚Äù


 Back to top

title: Purity Kwamboka
text: Back to top

title: Martin M Thendu
text: Back to top

title: Salmon Gowa
text:
Salmon Gowa is a software developer with a passion for using technology to address public health challenges. Proficient in software development and data analysis, he‚Äôs eager to create impactful, open-source tools to support evidence-based policymaking in Kenya.

title: Pre-Hackathon Reading Material
text:
To ensure all participants are equipped to make the most of the hackathon, we‚Äôve compiled a list of pre-read materials and resources. These resources cover essential skills for collaborative coding, R programming, and Git/GitHub workflows.



Git and GitHub: Collaborative coding will be a core component of the hackathon. Please review the following materials to ensure you‚Äôre familiar with these tools:

Introduction to GitHub
GitHub for Beginners
More GitHub Tips

R Programming: Many of the hackathon activities will involve R. The following resources will help you get up to speed:

Introduction to R
R for Data Science

R Package Development: For those interested in contributing to package development or using custom R packages:

R Packages Book





Before the event, ensure the following are installed and set up on your laptop:

R
RStudio
Git

If you need assistance with installation, refer to the guides linked above, or feel free to reach out to us prior to the hackathon.



For any queries about the resources or preparation, contact:

Waithera Mwangi: waithera.mwangi@cema.africa
Noel Likalamu: noel.likalamu@cema.africa

For any queries about setting your software up, contact:

OJ Watson: o.watson15@imperial.ac.uk

By familiarising yourself with these resources, you‚Äôll be ready to contribute effectively and make the most of your hackathon experience.
We look forward to seeing you all in Nairobi soon!

title: Hackathon Outcomes and Opportunities
text:
A GitHub repository has been created to house the outputs from all six working groups. It contains the code, data, and resources developed during the hackathon, ensuring these contributions remain accessible and reusable by the broader public health and scientific communities. You can explore it through the Github Orgnaization.



A manuscript is being prepared to describe the lessons learned from this hackathon. This document aims to provide valuable insights and a practical guide for others who may wish to organise similar events in the future. It will include a detailed account of the methods, challenges faced, and solutions implemented during the hackathon.



The hackathon website serves as a central hub, hosting all the materials, slides, and resources used throughout the event. It provides participants and others interested in the hackathon with comprehensive access to the information needed to replicate or build upon the event. This website is an enduring resource that supports knowledge sharing and capacity building.

title: Hackathon Outcomes and Opportunities
text:
Submit Your Work
We encourage all teams to consider how their hackathon projects can have a lasting impact. Beyond presenting at conferences, think about collaborating with new partners, publishing in journals, or applying for funding to take your ideas further.
Stay tuned for more updates, and let us know if you have questions about submitting your work or applying for funding opportunities.

title: Hackathon Outcomes and Opportunities
text:
Thinking about other conferences?
If there are other meetings or conferences you are interested in, please let us know. And you can use your newly learnt Github skills to make a pull request to the data/conferences.csv to share it.

title: Bridging the Gap Hackathon
text:
20-24 January 2025, Nairobi, Kenya
The ‚ÄúBridging the Gap Hackathon‚Äù is a 5-day event to bring together public health decision-makers, developers, technical experts, and academics and researchers to create free, open-source resources to support and facilitate evidence-informed decision making and address health policy needs in Kenya.

title: Bridging the Gap Hackathon
text:
Background
Experiences during the COVID-19 pandemic highlighted the challenges decision makers face in interpreting and using analytics for public health policy. To respond to these challenges, researchers at the MRC Centre for Global Infectious Disease Analysis (MRC-GIDA) at Imperial College London and the Center for Epidemiological Modelling and Analysis (CEMA) at the University of Nairobi are currently conducting a research study to explore how the gap between quantitative scientists and policymakers, especially in resource-constrained settings can be bridged.

title: Bridging the Gap Hackathon
text:
Who Should Attend
The hackathon aims to include a diverse audience, who will either contribute to idea generation or developing the identified software tools. The latter activity will include core training on collaborative coding best practices, which will be strengthened by the delivery of pre-hackathon virtual training courses and teaching material for enrolled participants.

Health Decision-Makers & Providers: Ministry of Health officials, health organizations and public health specialists who provide insights based on real-world public health needs and/or ensure developed tools address practical challenges.
Developers and Technical Experts: Individuals proficient in R programming, version control using Git and GitHub, epidemiological modelling, and software development.
Academics and Researchers: Participants from various Kenyan institutions, not limited to CEMA, who are involved in infectious disease modelling and public health data analysis.

title: Bridging the Gap Hackathon
text:
Hackathon Schedule

Day 1: Foundations and Group Formation

Introductions, icebreaker activities, and team building exercises.
Sharing of real-world challenges presented by Ministry of Health, health organizations and/or public health specialists.
Formation of interdisciplinary teams focused on specific public health challenges.

Days 2-4: Coding and Collaboration

Overview of Git, Github and collaborative coding practices (GitHub training should have been completed before attending the course).
Dedicated project work time with guidance from experienced facilitators.
Continuous interaction and feedback sessions to refine ideas and approaches.

Day 5: Presentation, Feedback and Next Steps

Teams present their minimum viable products to Ministry of Health representatives and other stakeholders.
Constructive feedback and discussions on the relevance and potential impact of the tools developed.

title: Bridging the Gap Hackathon
text:
Venue
The hackathon will be hosted by the Center for Epidemiological Modelling and Analysis (CEMA), and will take place at:
Nairobi Safari Club by Swiss-Belhotel, University Wy, Nairobi, Kenya Google Maps

title: Bridging the Gap Hackathon
text:
Sponsors
We are extremely grateful to our sponsors for the hackathon:

MRC Centre for Global Infectious Disease Analysis at Imperial College London (MR/X020258/1) for their support of the hackathon, including supporting researchers from Kenya and the United Kingdom to attend and providing resources for the hackathon.
Wellcome for funding the study inspiring the hackathon (‚ÄúLeveraging forecasts to optimise decision making‚Äù - 228271/Z/23/Z), which supported the original Ideathon team to travel for the hackathon.
The Gates Foundation (INV-044079) for supporting involvement of CEMA staff in the hackathon.

title: Jeanette Dawa
text:
Jeanette Dawa (MBChB, MSc, PhD) is a public health specialist/epidemiologist with a background in medicine, public health and infectious disease modelling.


 Back to top

title: Lilith Whittles
text:
Lilith Whittles is a researcher at Imperial College London, studying the transmission of infectious diseases through human populations. Her work spans a broad spectrum: from epidemic response to mpox, COVID-19 and group A streptococcus in the UK and Europe, to reducing the impact of globally endemic sexually transmitted infections such as gonorrhoea, HIV and HSV-2.


 Back to top

title: Cosmas Biwott
text:
Cosmas Biwott is a statistician at the University of Nairobi‚Äôs Centre for Epidemiological Modelling and Analysis (UoN-CEMA). Specializing in applying advanced statistical methods to health data, driving evidence-based decision-making to improve public health outcomes.


 Back to top

title: Preston Osoro
text:
Preston is a software developer with expertise in building APIs and data management systems, including patient management APIs. He is passionate about leveraging technology to solve real-world public health challenges.


 Back to top

title: Sabine Van Elsland
text:
Sabine van Elsland is the external relationships and communications manager at the MRC Centre for Global Infectious Disease Analysis at Imperial College London. Sabine is a trained infectious disease epidemiologist with a background in public health and health systems research. She has a passion for sustainable knowledge translation (evidence to policy decision making) and transparent, accessible science communication.


 Back to top

title: Evans Omondi
text:
Evans Omondi is a mathematician and Post-Doctoral Research Scientist (Mathematical modeler) at the African Population and Health Research Center (APHRC) in Kenya. I have a broad background in the application of mathematical modeling applied to biology, with particular expertise in dynamical systems and stochastic processes for modeling infectious diseases.


 Back to top

title: Pete Winskill
text:
Pete Winskill is a Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation-funded research fellow at the MRC Centre for Global Infectious Disease Analysis, Imperial College London and the Director of the Translational Modelling Hub. He leads the development of a global malaria modelling framework, linking the Imperial malariasimulation model to primary data to support global, national, and sub-national malaria modelling requests.


 Back to top

title: Katy Gaythorpe
text:
Dr Katy Gaythorpe is the research lead of the Vaccine Impact Modelling Consortium (VIMC, https://www.vaccineimpact.org/) and a lecturer in the epidemiology of vaccine-preventable diseases (VPDs) at Imperial College London. Her research focuses on developing mathematical models of infectious diseases such as yellow fever and others to assess the health impacts of vaccination. Dr Gaythorpe is particularly interested in the implications of climate change for climate-sensitive VPD control.


 Back to top

title: Paul Lietar
text:
Paul Li√©tar is a senior research software engineer at Imperial College London, working on building software tools to assist scientists in their research.


 Back to top

title: Jackline Mosinya Nyaberi
text:
Nyaberi is a public health and health systems expert researcher at the School of Public Health, Jomo Kenyatta University of Agriculture and Technology. She is an accomplished Global Health leader and advisor. She is an inaugural Fellow of the Kofi Annan (She is a such a resource for the continent and beyond). She is a 24/7 mentor to aspiring leaders in professional and Personal Development. She is a holistic trainer, mentor and coach at Authentic Leadership for Development (ALD) for Corporate Solutions. She is an author of ‚Äú101 Authentic Leadership Lessons: Impacting African Leaders. Jackline‚Äôs career has focused on strengthening ethics, leadership and governance, health systems, and public health leadership to improve infectious disease preparedness and to reduce mortality, morbidity, and disability in vulnerable communities. Her career accomplishments include formulating new health programs, policies, and strategies in 55 Africa Union Member states to support pandemic preparedness plans, health workforce planning, leadership and governance, and strengthening health systems. Jackline is inspired to mentor adolescents, women, and girls, provides basic school items for low-income children in rural settings, and founded Ayanna Health Foundation, a non-profit which provides mentorship, empowerment and health services to vulnerable populations and mentorship. Jackline holds a Master of Public Health from Maseno University in Kenya, a Master of Global Bioethics from Anahuac University in Mexico, and a Ph.D.¬†in Public Health from Kenyatta University in Kenya. Jackline was named a 2021 Inaugural Kofi Annan Global Health Leadership Fellow by the Kofi Annan Foundation, Africa CDC and African Union. Long term, Jackline hopes to continue her work in strengthening public health systems in Africa and beyond and to activate the next generation to become transformational leaders. She dreams to support not only health systems in Africa to experience a paradigm shift in governance and leadership, but also to support all interconnected ecosystems of all stakeholders to foster health and wellbeing for all generations. jnyaberij@gmail.com https://www.linkedin.com/in/mosinyanyaberi/


 Back to top

title: Michelle Mumbua
text: Back to top

title: Arani Bonsoul
text:
I am Bonsoul Arani Bosire, a data scientist and analyst with over three years of experience in the data industry. I specialize in leveraging machine learning, statistical analysis, and scalable Python solutions to drive business growth and deliver actionable insights. My expertise spans data visualization, competitive analysis, and sales forecasting, enabling me to improve processes, optimize resources, and enhance decision-making.


 Back to top

title: Veronicah Gathoni
text:
veronica chege is a software engineer focused on identifying and addressing gaps in the healthcare system. With a strong problem-solving mindset, she collaborates with subject-matter experts to apply engineering solutions to improve healthcare outcomes.


 Back to top

title: Peninna Mwongeli Nzoka
text:
Peninna Nzoka is a post-graduate researcher in Health Systems Strengthening (HSS) and a Health Policymaker/ Manager at the Ministry of Health, Kenya advocating for the translation of policy content into action.


 Back to top

title: Ivy Kombe
text:
Ivy Kombe is a computational epidemiologist at the Kenya Medical Research Institute - Wellcome Trust, specializing in mathematical models of infectious disease dynamics, with experience in modeling HIV, COVID-19, and respiratory syncytial virus.


 Back to top

title: Mutono Nyamai
text:
Mutono is a data scientist currently using applied epidemiological modelling techniques to provide evidence for control and elimination of Neglected Tropical Diseases.


 Back to top

title: Kibet Immanuel Ngeno
text:
I am kibet Immanuel, a full-stack software engineer with a passion for developing innovative solutions that bridge technology and real-world needs. My expertise lies in creating scalable and impactful software especially in collaborative environments.


 Back to top

title: Paula Christen
text:
Paula Christen is social scientist and infectious disease epidemiologist specialized in researching, identifying and developing interventions enabling knowledge translation from infectious disease models to public health policy and programs.


 Back to top

title: Tabitha Okech
text:
Tabitha Okech is a dedicated Public Health Practitioner and Pharmacist based in Nairobi, Kenya, with over a decade of experience in managing preventive and promotive public health programs.


 Back to top

title: Fred Nyamitago Monari
text:
Fred Nyamitago Monari is a statistician and lecturer at Kisii University with extensive expertise in applied statistics, epidemiological modeling, and public health data analysis. His work focuses on leveraging advanced statistical methods and interdisciplinary collaboration to address pressing challenges in health, climate, and environmental research.


 Back to top

title: Stephanie Kamunya
text:
Stephanie is a postdoctoral research fellow at CEMA with a PhD focusing on antimalarial drug discovery, currently applying her experience in malaria research to mathematical modelling.


 Back to top

title: Oliver (OJ) Watson
text:
OJ Watson is a lecturer and Schmidt AI in science fellow at Imperial College London, with a background in infectious disease modelling in malaria, and interest in pandemic preparedness.


 Back to top

title: Waithera Mwangi
text:
Waithera is an Administration Officer at CEMA, dedicated to ensuring smooth operations and effective coordination for trainings that take place at the organisation.

title: Noel Likalamu

title: Setting Up Git and GitHub on Mac
text:
Introduction
Welcome to the guide for setting up Git and GitHub on Mac. This guide assumes no prior coding or Git experience.
We will cover:

Downloading and installing Git.
Verifying the installation.
Generating an SSH key.
Adding the SSH key to GitHub.
Linking the SSH key with RStudio.

title: Setting Up Git and GitHub on Mac
text:
Step 1: Install Git

Open the Terminal application on your Mac.
Check if Git is already installed by running:
git --version
If Git is not installed, you will see a prompt to install the Xcode Command Line Tools:

Click Install and follow the on-screen instructions.

Once installed, verify Git by running:
git --version

You should see a version number, e.g., git version 2.x.x.

title: Setting Up Git and GitHub on Mac
text:
Step 2: Generate an SSH Key

Open the Terminal application.
Run the following command:
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your_email@example.com"

Replace your_email@example.com with your GitHub email address.

When prompted:

Press Enter to save the key to the default location.
(Optional) Enter a passphrase for added security.

Your SSH key will be saved to a default location, e.g., /Users/YourName/.ssh/id_ed25519.

title: Setting Up Git and GitHub on Mac
section: Step 3: Add the SSH Key to GitHub
text:
Step 3: Add the SSH Key to GitHub

Display your public SSH key:

Run the following command in Terminal:
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub
Copy the output (Cmd + C).

Log in to your GitHub account.
Go to Settings > SSH and GPG keys.
Click New SSH key:

Title: Give your key a name (e.g., ‚ÄúMy Mac‚Äù).
Key: Paste the copied key into the text box.

Click Add SSH key.
Confirm your password if prompted.

title: Setting Up Git and GitHub on Mac
text:
Step 4: Test the SSH Connection

Open the Terminal application.
Run the following command:
ssh -T git@github.com
If successful, you will see a message like:
Hi username! You've successfully authenticated, but GitHub does not provide shell access.

If there‚Äôs an error, check that the SSH key was added correctly.

title: Setting Up Git and GitHub on Mac
section: Step 5: Link SSH Key with RStudio
text:
Step 5: Link SSH Key with RStudio

Open RStudio.
Go to Tools > Global Options.
In the left-hand menu, click on Git/SVN.
Check the box labeled Enable version control interface for RStudio.
Under the Git executable field, ensure the path points to the Git installation, e.g., /usr/bin/git.
Click Apply and then OK.

title: Setting Up Git and GitHub on Mac
section: Step 6: Configure SSH Key in RStudio
text:
Step 6: Configure SSH Key in RStudio

Open the Terminal tab in RStudio (found at the bottom-right of the screen).
Verify the SSH key is correctly set up by running:
ssh -T git@github.com
If successful, proceed to the next step.

title: Setting Up Git and GitHub on Mac
section: Step 7: Clone a Repository in RStudio
text:
Step 7: Clone a Repository in RStudio

Go to your GitHub repository.
Click the green Code button and select SSH.
Copy the SSH link (e.g., git@github.com:username/repo.git).
In RStudio, go to File > New Project > Version Control > Git.
Paste the SSH link into the Repository URL field.
Choose a directory to save the project and click Create Project.

title: Setting Up Git and GitHub on Mac
text:
Congratulations!
You have successfully:

Installed Git.
Verified the installation.
Created and added an SSH key to GitHub.
Linked the SSH key with RStudio.

You are now ready to use the Git GUI in RStudio to manage your projects and collaborate effectively!

title: Setting Up Git and GitHub on Windows
text:
Step 1: Download and Install Git

Go to the Git website: https://git-scm.com.
Click on Download for Windows.
Run the downloaded .exe file.
Follow the installation steps:

Use the default settings.
Click ‚ÄúNext‚Äù for all options unless you have specific requirements.

Click Finish when done.

title: Setting Up Git and GitHub on Windows
text:
Step 2: Check Git is Installed

Open the Command Prompt:

Press Win + R, type cmd, and press Enter.

Type the following command and press Enter:
git --version
You should see a version number, e.g., git version 2.x.x.

If you see an error, repeat the installation steps.

title: Setting Up Git and GitHub on Windows
text:
Step 3: Generate an SSH Key

Open the Git Bash application (installed with Git).
Run the following command:
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your_email@example.com"

Replace your_email@example.com with your GitHub email address.

When prompted:

Press Enter to save the key to the default location.
(Optional) Enter a passphrase for added security.

Your SSH key will be saved to a default location, e.g., C:\Users\YourName\.ssh\id_ed25519.

title: Setting Up Git and GitHub on Windows
section: Step 4: Add the SSH Key to GitHub
text:
Step 4: Add the SSH Key to GitHub

Display your public SSH key:

Run the following command in Git Bash:
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub
Copy the output (Ctrl + C).

Log in to your GitHub account.
Go to Settings > SSH and GPG keys.
Click New SSH key:

Title: Give your key a name (e.g., ‚ÄúMy Laptop‚Äù).
Key: Paste the copied key into the text box.

Click Add SSH key.
Confirm your password if prompted.

title: Setting Up Git and GitHub on Windows
text:
Step 5: Test the SSH Connection

Open Git Bash.
Run the following command:
ssh -T git@github.com
If successful, you will see a message like:
Hi username! You've successfully authenticated, but GitHub does not provide shell access.

If there‚Äôs an error, check that the SSH key was added correctly.

title: Setting Up Git and GitHub on Windows
section: Step 6: Link SSH Key with RStudio
text:
Step 6: Link SSH Key with RStudio

Open RStudio.
Go to Tools > Global Options.
In the left-hand menu, click on Git/SVN.
Check the box labeled Enable version control interface for RStudio.
Under the Git executable field, ensure the path points to the Git installation, e.g., C:\Program Files\Git\bin\git.exe.
Click Apply and then OK.

title: Setting Up Git and GitHub on Windows
section: Step 7: Configure SSH Key in RStudio
text:
Step 7: Configure SSH Key in RStudio

Open the Terminal tab in RStudio (found at the bottom-right of the screen).
Verify the SSH key is correctly set up by running:
ssh -T git@github.com
If successful, proceed to the next step.

title: Setting Up Git and GitHub on Windows
section: Step 8: Clone a Repository in RStudio
text:
Step 8: Clone a Repository in RStudio

Go to your GitHub repository.
Click the green Code button and select SSH.
Copy the SSH link (e.g., git@github.com:username/repo.git).
In RStudio, go to File > New Project > Version Control > Git.
Paste the SSH link into the Repository URL field.
Choose a directory to save the project and click Create Project.

title: Setting Up Git and GitHub on Windows
text:
Congratulations!
You have successfully:

Installed Git.
Verified the installation.
Created and added an SSH key to GitHub.
Linked the SSH key with RStudio.

You are now ready to use the Git GUI in RStudio to manage your projects and collaborate effectively!

title: Day 5
text:
Welcome to Day 5

Challenge Presentation Day
Structure for the presentations:

15 minutes for presentation
5 minutes for question

We will break for tea and coffee half way
After the presentations we will conclude with a set of thanks and reflections on the hackathon.

title: Day 5
section: 1. What aspects made the hackathon effective?
text:
1. What aspects made the hackathon effective?

Key Themes:

Team Diversity: Cross-disciplinary groups brought different perspectives and skillsets.
Clear Goals: Having structured daily goals and well-defined problem statements was valued.
Interactive Environment: Activities like icebreakers, debriefs and engaging decision-makers fostered collaboration.

Supporting Quotes:

‚ÄúBeing paired up with people of different backgrounds and skills was useful for cohesion of the team.‚Äù ‚Äî Fred Nyamitago Monari
‚ÄúThe challenges were clearly defined, making it easy to hit the ground running.‚Äù ‚Äî Pete Winskill
‚ÄúRegular breaks, ice breaking, collaboration, Hacking itself and Debriefing.‚Äù ‚Äî Tabitha Okech

title: Day 5
section: 2. What aspects of the hackathon could have been improved?
text:
2. What aspects of the hackathon could have been improved?

Key Themes:

More Time: Many participants wanted extended durations for deeper work.
Pre-event Preparation: Better onboarding and earlier dissemination of problem statements.
Environment: Preferences for better-lit and outdoor spaces for breaks.

Supporting Quotes:

‚ÄúHopefully, the real work could start sooner, by day 1 or 2 latest to allow more time to build the models and achieve quality work.‚Äù ‚Äî Fred Nyamitago Monari
‚ÄúWe should increase the time of the hackathon to 2 weeks to allow effective deliverables.‚Äù ‚Äî Lilith Whittles
‚ÄúThe venue was good, but a room with daylight would be extremely beneficial to the state of the participants.‚Äù ‚Äî Anonymous

title: Day 5
section: 3. What aspects helped teams to collaborate effectively?
text:
3. What aspects helped teams to collaborate effectively?

Key Themes:

Interdisciplinary Collaboration: Teams with diverse roles (developers, policymakers, facilitators) functioned effectively.
Icebreakers and Social Activities: Jenga and informal group activities eased communication barriers.
Decision-Maker Involvement: Having decision-makers within teams improved the relevance of outcomes.

Supporting Quotes:

‚ÄúThe team organisation balance‚Ä¶ a software engineer, data scientist, facilitators, and the decision maker in one table.‚Äù ‚Äî Anonymous
‚ÄúHaving the decision-makers in the room was excellent. Icebreaking activities helped us make progress.‚Äù ‚Äî Anonymous
‚ÄúThe family groups created with hackers, facilitators, and decision-makers captured the reality of the problems we were solving.‚Äù ‚Äî John Ojal

title: Day 5
section: 4. What were the merits of the hackathon for participants?
text:
4. What were the merits of the hackathon for participants?

Key Themes:

Skill Development: Practical learning in coding, modelling, and collaboration.
Networking Opportunities: Building connections with professionals across fields.
Enjoyable Environment: Participants felt part of a family and enjoyed working in their families.

Supporting Quotes:

‚ÄúLearning Git and GitHub, coding aspects like commit, push, pull, and merge.‚Äù ‚Äî Katy Gaythorpe
‚ÄúMeeting, working, learning from, and teaching the team!‚Äù ‚Äî Anonymous
The participants were well-motivated and great fun to work with‚Äîthe Jenga and introductory sessions meant we had quite a relaxed atmosphere, and this really helped with generating ideas.‚Äù ‚Äî Francis Motiri

title: Day 5
section: 5. What components were effective/could be improved for knowledge translation?
text:
5. What components were effective/could be improved for knowledge translation?

Key Themes:

Focused Problem Statements: Clear and concise problems made the tools practical.
Longer Working Time: Extended durations were suggested for deeper exploration and refinement.
Pre-event Planning: Early provision of datasets and structured pre-hackathon planning were beneficial (but could have been even earlier!).

Supporting Quotes:

‚ÄúFocused problem statements streamline efforts and lead to more impactful outcomes.‚Äù ‚Äî Anonymous
‚ÄúIn the future, it could be helpful to have more time for testing and refining the final solutions. This will allow the participants to see the project through to a higher level of innovation.‚Äù ‚Äî John Ojal
‚ÄúPlan and work pre-hackathon to help with working plans and structure.‚Äù ‚Äî Peter Waweru Mugo
‚ÄúReceiving datasets ahead of time might have helped a little.‚Äù ‚Äî Anonymous

title: Day 5
text:
Hackathon Milestones Reached:

Total number of Github Commits across groups:

542 Commits üéá

36 Individuals üíë

Total number of biscuits consumed:

196 Biscuits (at least‚Ä¶) üç™

note3

+ Imperial facilitators

title: Feedback
text:
We hope you‚Äôre enjoying the hackathon and having a great time collaborating, learning, and innovating. Your feedback is crucial in helping us improve and make this event even better for everyone. Thank you for helping us make this event the best it can be!


We‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs about the logistics, content, or anything else. Please take a moment to share your feedback through the link below. Your responses are completely anonymous, and we‚Äôll aim to address your suggestions daily throughout the week.
Provide Your Daily Feedback Here



We are are keen to understand how we could have improved this hackathon, what worked well and what did not. Please take a moment at the end of Day 5 to share your feedback through the link below.
Provide Your End of Hackathon Feedback Here
